45451.base_text: Time seemed to snap and twist back on itself in opposing directions, both too fast and too slow. Terror struck me like lightning, searing me with unbearable matching thoughts: he’s going to die and there’s nothing I can do to help him.

45451.base_text: Then he grabbed the edge of the next doorframe down and his body slammed against the horizontal door beneath. I watched the bottoms of his sneakers as they kicked and flailed at the smooth beige wall, scrabbling for purchase.

45451.base_text: “Are you okay?” I shouted up at him, or something equally useless. My lungs were clenched so tight that for a minute I couldn’t breathe back in.

I could see muscles trembling even from here. He clung to the wall quivering like a caught-out insect, paralyzed with indecision.

45451.base_text: “You’re okay.” I tried to keep my voice light, in control, willing confidence into it and up to him. My mind thrummed as it raced to find him a way out. He was still clipped on to the climbing rope but the grapple now swayed useless beneath him. The hallway pit ran featureless above and below the doorframe he clung to: there was nothing else to get a grip on, not for a dozen feet in either direction.

45451.base_text: We made it to the top, in the end. It took a series of shorter climbs to each sideways room, treating them like miniature base camps, places to rest before flinging the grapple up another dozen feet to the next door, the next cube of safety; testing each set of the grapple more thoroughly, belaying each other as best we could in the patently unsafe circumstances. But at length, we’d made it back out.

45451.base_text: The tape had run to the end, so we backed it up a bit and hit play. To our dismay, the ropes were going over the edge right to the end; whatever happened, it had been after the tape ran out. Niko held down the rewind button and we settled in for a long haul. We spooled back through the whole tape, but nothing changed: it was two hours of motionless footage of the hallway and our ropes. Finally we saw ourselves spring back up from the pit at high speed, first me and then him; dicker with the grapples and rope, then zip over to the camera to turn it on. The tape clunked to a stop.

Something jostled the camera and it surged forward with the tide, water sloshing against the lens, until the scalding stream carried it over the edge and it fell, straight down into that boiling pit, surrounded by water on every side, gathering speed, falling into wet and steaming dark, faster and faster and faster…

45451.base_text: “Did I ever tell you,” he finally said, “about that time I went camping by myself, up in Brushwillow?” I shook my head. “Used to do that a lot, after the, uh. Accident.”

variants.text: “Did I ever tell you,” he finally said, “about that time I went camping by myself, up in Brushwillow?” I shook my head. “Used to do that a lot, after the, uh. Accident.”

45451.base_text: I took that in. He hadn’t brought it up in a long time. Neither had I.

variants.text: I took that in. He hadn’t brought it up in a long time. Neither had I.

45451.base_text: “I went by myself, cause I didn’t want a lot of people around just then, and it’s easier than twisting people’s arms to get them to come with you. Planning around schedules, all that bullshit.” He shifted into citation voice. “‘The one who goes alone can start today; but the one who travels with another must wait until they are ready.’”

45451.base_text: “Yeah, Thoreau. You quote that one a lot.”

variants.text: “Yeah, Thoreau. You quote that one a lot.”

45451.base_text: He shrugged. “I like it up there. Anyway.”

variants.text: He shrugged. “I like it up there. Anyway.”

45451.base_text: I waited, staring into the whorled beige universe of the carpet.

variants.text: I waited, staring into the whorled beige universe of the carpet.

45451.base_text: “So this one night I’m up there, alone. I’m in my tent, and it’s dark. Cloudy, no moon. I’m sleeping fine, on my back, you know, head up against the edge of the tent. And then I wake up, cause I hear something, just outside.”

variants.text: “So this one night I’m up there, alone. I’m in my tent, and it’s dark. Cloudy, no moon. I’m sleeping fine, on my back, you know, head up against the edge of the tent. And then I wake up, cause I hear something, just outside.”

45451.base_text: He sucked on the cigarette. “Something breathing. Low, hissing, gurgling breathing. Sounded huge, like a bear or something, a big-ass wolf. And it was right on the other side of the tent flap. Inches from my face. Like something had pressed its muzzle against the nylon, that thin nothing sheet of ultralight fabric, and was waiting. It could smell my breath, maybe. Waiting for me to move. And as soon as I did, it would get me.

45451.base_text: “I still remember what that felt like. Fucking terrifying.

variants.text: “I still remember what that felt like. Fucking terrifying.

45451.base_text: “I was too scared to move, so I lay there a long time, hoping it would go away. But it didn’t. The thing stayed where it was. Kept making those horrible breathing sounds. Inhale. Exhale. Raspy, choking.”

45451.base_text: He flicked the cigarette onto the carpet, rubbed it out with his foot.

45451.base_text: “And then I realized where the sound was coming from. The breathing was coming from me. I was sleeping on a root or something, my head had gotten into some funny angle. I was snoring, basically, and woke myself up. But I didn’t realize what woke me was a sound I was making myself.”

45451.base_text: “You’re saying maybe there’s not… a thing down there. That somehow, all of it is us.”

45451.base_text: “Echoes,” he said. “Reflections. The rooms are reflections of our shitty old house, and the things we’re seeing, experiencing down there, maybe they’re not alive. We’re causing them, somehow. And now we’re ascribing intentionality to side effects. Jumping at our own shadows.” He lay back down on his sleeping bag, staring up at the ceiling.

45451.base_text: I remembered something from a neurobiology class. “Did you know there are more neurons going from your brain to your eyes than in the other direction?”

45451.base_text: “From your brain to your eyes,” I repeated, “not the other way around.”

45451.base_text: “It does if you realize that vision is mostly the brain telling the eyes what it expects them to see.” I rubbed my face again, trying to wipe off the exhaustion. “We think we have two little cameras in our head. We don’t. They’re little yes-men, reassuring us nothing unexpected is happening. That’s why that trick works, with the guy in the gorilla suit. You ever see that video in school?”

But you don’t see him the first time, because you’re watching the ball. Then you watch it again looking for him and your mind’s blown.” He smiled faintly. “Dude in my high school science class swore the teacher changed the tape.”

45451.base_text: “So maybe we’re somehow looking at this wrong,” I finally said. “We’re not seeing something. We keep saying it doesn’t make any sense. Maybe we’re just not seeing it the right way.”

45451.base_text: “Even if we are the wolf,” Niko muttered, just as I was about to drift off, “that doesn’t mean it’s not trying to kill us.”

45451.base_text: I got fired from my job, which was fair enough; I’d missed two shifts in the past week. I got a nosebleed during the meeting with my supervisor. He told me to go home and take care of myself. I was halfway home before I remembered that phrase has a positive meaning, too.

45451.base_text: Something was in my room when I got back. I stood outside the closed door, dried blood on my face, listening. It sounded like an elephant. Heavy, clopping footfalls made the floorboards groan. Wet, agitated breathing rasped. Dust motes danced at my feet in a strange breeze, sucked under and pushed back out through the space below the closed door, rhythmic. Air moved with faint fleshy sounds, like a hundred quiet people flapping their arms, flailing.

45451.base_text: I crept away, miserable, and by the time I came back with Niko and he threw open the door in some play at courage, there was nothing there.

45451.base_text: I collapsed into his arms, sobbing, and he let me stay there for a while until I’d calmed down. I clung to him, afraid if I loosened my grip he’d disappear. Like dad, tucking me in. Gone between one blink and the next.

45451.base_text: He had a perpetual headache now. He kept describing it with the word “piercing” and only that word, as if clinging to the sound of it. Like using a different one would acknowledge the pain too had changed, grown worse, was no longer caged by the word he’d picked to trap it. I could see how much it hurt him to think, to make words, to move around. He ground his teeth. He was being worn down.

45451.base_text: My headaches were getting worse, too, but it wasn’t the pain that bothered me. It was the strain of always having them that wore on me. Of wondering if I’d have to deal with them for the rest of my life.

variants.text: [Paragraph not present in this version]

45451.base_text: We left to explore down the slippery tunnel late that night. It might have made more sense to start after a good night’s rest, but neither of us could sleep, and spending so much time down there meant night and day were becoming academic concepts anyway. Niko caffeined up (I was jittery enough already), and we loaded our packs with canned food and power bars, thick gloves, and crampons from the sporting goods store. “12 points of contact ensures solid grip on ice,” the box had said. We didn’t expect the manufacturer had tested them on slime-covered carpet, but it was the best we could do.

variants.text: [Paragraph not present in this version]

45451.base_text: In my pack was also a gun. I bought it from a place I’d driven past every day on my way to work but never gone into until that morning. The friendly clerk agreed to waive the mandatory waiting period in exchange for the last of my ATM cash. I didn’t tell Niko about the gun. I thought it would make me feel safer but it just felt heavy.

45451.base_text: It had been a hot day and the old house clung to that heat through the night with grim brick desperation. Descending into chillier air was a relief. With every step down the headaches diminished, our mood improved. It was almost addictive, being down there.

45451.base_text: We retraced our route through the upper halls to the top of the shaft and reset the grapples. This time Niko hammered them into the doorjamb, face set, until he’d driven the steel spikes three inches into the wood. Even so, neither of us really expected they’d still be there when we got back.

45451.base_text: Getting down was a familiar exercise now, danger mitigated by procedure and repetition. We retraced our route to the tiled room with the sink. The water was still running, hot and steaming, rushing across the floor to the corner with its angled hallway lined with slimy black carpet. We shined our lights down the hot throat and the steam grabbed their brightness, bounced it back to us maliciously. We couldn’t see more than a few body lengths down.

45451.base_text: We pulled on the crampons and the heavy gloves. Harness, rope, knots. Check. Niko pounded two new Grip Monkeys into either side of the angled tunnel entrance. We tied on. Double-check.

45451.base_text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

variants.text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

45451.base_text: It was slow, hot work. Once we got inside the slanted hall, the steam was oppressive, everywhere: we were instantly drenched with it, like rot-smelling sweat. Even with the crampons our feet slipped. The sludge was deep and slick, a stew of algae and mold and fungal slimes, green-black and stinking of putrefying jungle, of horrible things happening under your carpet, inside your walls. We held tight to the ropes with steam-wet gloves. The walls and floor twisted and bent as we descended, as if the constant moisture had warped them, but the downward angle stayed relentless.

45451.base_text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

variants.text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

45451.base_text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

variants.text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

45451.base_text: All at once we were sliding. Our ropes had gone slack in our hands, no longer connected to anything. There was no time to dig in the crampons; we were already moving too fast, careening down like a grotesque slalom. Neither of us screamed, focused I guess on trying to grab hold of something, anything, but there were no doorways, no light fixtures, nothing but the thick hot slime and the scalding water. I tried to dig my feet into the oozing carpet but my loose rope had entangled me, my pack was in my way, my face was smeared with scalding gunk and I couldn’t open my eyes.

45451.base_text: My hand closed on Niko’s leg and I grabbed it. A moment later the floor angle shifted and he cried out, threw his body sideways, brought us both to a shuddering, squelchy stop.

Niko reached out to grab one with his free hand, but his weight shifted, and he had to throw the hand back against a wall to re-brace, cursing. I tried to snag them with my foot, but didn’t even come close. They vanished down the tunnel, trailing rope.

45451.base_text: Niko’s face was tight. He tilted his head down toward me. “This was a mistake. God, we’re so fucking stupid. Ryan, man. We have to go back.”

45451.base_text: “Hang on,” I gasped, head filled with the roaring of the water, blinking gunk from my eyes. “Don’t panic. We can do this.”

45451.base_text: “There’s nothing good up there. Nothing right.” I kicked my foot for purchase, managed to rest at least some weight on a hidden protuberance. “Besides, nothing’s changed. The plan’s still the same.”

45451.base_text: “So let’s find out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”

45451.base_text: “Because we don’t even know if there is a bottom.” His face was blotched red with fury, with sweat, with the scorching heat of the air. “Halfway? We have no fucking idea how deep this goes. I should have said this a long time ago. You’re obsessed. You get obsessed a lot, man, let it drag you down. Your stupid records.” He took a deep breath. “Well now you’re obsessed with this place, and it’s blinding you. It’s feeding on you, your obsessions. Multiplying them. You can’t see it, or maybe you don’t want to, but I do. I’m looking right at it. Like the gorilla in the crowd.”

45451.base_text: “Our housemates,” I pushed, “when was the last time you hung out with any of them? Anyone other than me?” He stared back, seething. “Their names. I bet you can’t even remember their names.” I was bluffing. But could I remember them, either? Names, faces. No. There was nothing. None of those people mattered, not to me, not to us. We were the only thing that mattered. Getting back to where we’d been, what we’d had. What I’d wanted.

45451.base_text: He shook his head again, violent, like there was something inside it he wanted to dislodge. “You’re living in a fantasy,” he spat, “you always have been. I can’t be what you want me to be, okay? I can’t be what anyone fucking wants me to be. You all have these versions of me in your head, these ideal perfect Nikos, but they’re not real. I can’t live up to them.” He opened his eyes, stared yearningly back up the shaft. “Help me. If you really care about me, help me back up. Don’t be like everyone else. Don’t just fucking use me to get what you want.”

45451.base_text: “Going back’s not going to help. There’s no answers up there.” He wasn’t understanding. I reached for something else. “Those headaches aren’t going away. You think you can live with that pain? Forever?”

45451.base_text: “Better than being fucking dead!” He seemed to realize I wasn’t changing my mind, turned away to reach for a handhold, but there was nothing there, nothing to grip, and he scrabbled pathetically at the slime.

45451.base_text: “Is it?” I shouted, angry, desperate. I had to say something, something that would make him stay, keep him here, and my mouth raced ahead of me. “You won’t make it, up there, not with pain like that. We both know you won’t.”

45451.base_text: “You know exactly what it means,” I said, shaking. “Never really helped you. I’ve done nothing but help you. I’ve always been there for you. Every fucking time you fall I pick you back up. You’d be dead if it weren’t for me.”

45451.base_text: He shot me with a gaze of such cold fury I cringed. “You’re fucking poison,” he hissed, “you know that? A fucking snake. I wish you’d let me die that night. I wish we’d never met. Let go of me!”

45451.base_text: And his hand did close on something, and he pulled himself up, triumphant. His leg was slipping out of my hands, and I couldn’t bear for him to crawl away from me, couldn’t stand it, couldn’t handle the thought of going back up to that world, to any world where everything was wrong and nothing I wanted was possible, so I pulled. I pulled, too hard, and both his hands slipped, and he crashed back into me, only I wasn’t holding onto anything but him any more so both of us tumbled down, faster and faster, slipping and twisting and scraping together down the steepening blood-hot slope, down and down and down into darkness.

The hallway pit ran featureless above and below the doorframe he clung to: there was nothing else to get a grip on, not for a dozen feet in either direction.

But at length, we’d made it back out.

45452.base_text: The tape had run to the end, so we backed it up a bit and hit play. To our dismay, the ropes were going over the edge right to the end; whatever happened, it had been after the tape ran out. Niko held down the rewind button and we settled in for a long haul. We spooled back through the whole tape, but nothing changed: it was two hours of motionless footage of the hallway and our ropes. Finally we saw ourselves spring back up from the pit at high speed, first me and then him; dicker with the grapples and rope, then zip over to the camera to turn it on. The tape clunked to a stop.

45452.base_text: In some of these variations, Niko and I were boyfriends. A couple. I could tell from the words we used, the way we looked at each other. Nothing that would have been obvious to anyone but me. I replayed these scenes over and over, rewinding to catch the little glances, secret smiles.

45452.base_text: There were other, worse versions.

45452.base_text: There were dream-tapes where a gaunt Ryan and Niko with aged and wrinkled faces hobbled up to the camera in wonder, picked it up, passed it back and forth between them in awe. Like they’d been trapped down there for a lifetime. They pawed at the lens in a stupid glee, as if they’d forgotten what a camera even was. As if it might somehow be a portal back through time.

45452.base_text: There were tapes where we cursed out our watcher-selves, told them to go away, to never come back again, that what was down here would destroy us. There were others, far worse, where we grinned like sharks, invited ourselves to come down deep, and stay.

variants.text: [Paragraph not present in this version]

45452.base_text: There were versions where my acne was miraculously gone, where a version of myself that looked almost handsome checked ropes and called confidently down the shaft. There were versions where our voices were wrong, like they’d been spliced together from a dozen different tapes, some of the sounds played backwards, pitch-shifted, noise-reduced.

variants.text: [Paragraph not present in this version]

45452.base_text: There were versions of the pit with nothing else there: no grapples, no ropes, no us. There were versions where the carpet was crawling with beetles. There were versions where the walls were made of meat.

variants.text: [Paragraph not present in this version]

45452.base_text: There were tapes where I couldn’t see anything wrong, and those were the worst because I knew something was.

variants.text: There were tapes where I couldn’t see anything wrong, and those were the worst because I knew something was.
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45452.base_text: And on one tape—and I rewound and re-watched this over and over, in the dream—water from all the hallways poured into the pit, a four-sided waterfall. The carpets were black and sticky with moss trailing down into the vertical shaft, the air thick with steam. Something jostled the camera and it surged forward with the tide, water sloshing against the lens, until the scalding stream carried it over the edge and it fell, straight down into that boiling pit, surrounded by water on every side, gathering speed, falling into wet and steaming dark, faster and faster and faster…

45452.base_text: I would jerk awake at this point, coated in sweat, and try not to fall back asleep. But when I did I’d find myself rewinding the tape yet again and pressing play, hoping this time the footage would return to normal. It was always changed, and I’d have to watch it all over from the beginning, hoping this version would show something useful, a hint, a clue, an answer.

45452.base_text: “Our lease says no smoking in here,” I grunted, still shaking off nightmares.

45452.base_text: He took another drag. “Blow me.”

variants.text: He took another drag. “Blow me.”

45452.base_text: I laughed and he flashed me a wicked grin. It felt good to laugh. Even if it was a little bit forced, to make sure he knew that I knew he was kidding.

45452.base_text: Rubbing my eyes, I sat up in my sleeping bag. After a moment I scrunched over and lowered myself into the pit opposite him, still encased in my bag.

45452.base_text: We steeped in smoke and silence for a long minute.

45452.base_text: “Did I ever tell you,” he finally said, “about that time I went camping by myself, up in Brushwillow?” I shook my head. “Used to do that a lot, after the, uh. Accident.”

45452.base_text: “I went by myself, cause I didn’t want a lot of people around just then, and it’s easier than twisting people’s arms to get them to come with you. Planning around schedules, all that bullshit.” He shifted into citation voice. “‘The man who goes alone might start today, but if he travels with another he must wait till that other is ready.’”

45452.base_text: “So this one night I’m up there, alone. I’m in my tent, and it’s dark. Cloudy, no moon. I’m sleeping fine, on my back, you know, head up against the edge of the tent. And then I wake up, cause I hear something, just outside.”

And it was right on the other side of the tent flap. Inches from my face. Like something had pressed its muzzle against the nylon, that thin nothing sheet of ultralight fabric, and was waiting.

45452.base_text: “It does if you realize that vision is mostly the brain telling the eyes what it expects them to see.” I rubbed my face again, trying to wipe off the exhaustion. “We think we have two little cameras in our head. We don’t. They’re little yes-men, reassuring us nothing unexpected is happening. That’s why that trick works, with the guy in the gorilla suit. You ever see that video in school?”

45452.base_text: I tried to take a midterm and it was a disaster. I hadn’t been to class in weeks, which didn’t help, but everything I’d learned earlier had vanished from my brain, neurons reclaimed, I supposed, for more important things. Then I started hallucinating, questions and pencil marks multiplying and layering on themselves even when I looked up from the test, abstractions filling the darkened auditorium, and I had to flee, whispering a hurried apology to the T.A. that I was having a medical emergency. She told me to go home and take care of myself. I was halfway home before I remembered that phrase has a positive meaning, too.

45452.base_text: The sound was distorted, clipped, like a hundred recordings of voices thrown together unmixed, maxing out the dynamic range of reality. It was scream and cry and laughter and words and grunting and hum and song and cough all scraping against each other like geologic faults, painful and unsteady. Unwillingly I remembered how the history lady had looked, thought of the sound something like that might make if it knew what was happening to it, if it wasn’t just an optical illusion but, god, an event, a trauma; thought of the copies of myself I’d seen in the dim hallway that first night we went Downstairs and wondered what it would be like if there were a hundred of them all squeezed together in the space where only one should be, each trying to escape and become its own person; wondered whether this was all in my head or whether it mattered if it was; wondered if it mattered that all those voices, those screams and cries and giggles and moans, were all, unmistakably, my own.

Like using a different one would acknowledge the pain too had changed, grown worse, was no longer caged by the word he’d picked to trap it. I could see how much it hurt him to think, to make words, to move around. He ground his teeth. He stood up carefully now, putting a hand against the wall each time, as if his blood was fighting his heart’s attempts to lift it to his head, to keep it from being dragged back down.

45452.base_text: We left to explore down the slippery tunnel late that night. It might have made more sense to start after a good night’s rest, but neither of us could sleep, and spending so much time down there meant night and day were becoming academic concepts anyway. Niko caffeined up (I was jittery enough already), and we loaded our packs with canned food and power bars, thick gloves, and crampons from the sporting goods store. “12 points of contact ensures solid grip on ice,” the box had said. We didn’t expect the manufacturer had tested them on moldy carpet, but it was the best we could do.

45452.base_text: In my pack was also a gun. I bought it from a place I’d driven past every day on my way to work but never gone into until that morning. The friendly clerk agreed to waive the mandatory waiting period in exchange for the last of my ATM cash. I didn’t tell Niko about the gun. I thought it would make me feel safer but it just felt heavy.

We shined our lights down the hot throat and the steam grabbed their brightness, bounced it back to us innocently. We couldn’t see more than a few body lengths down.

45452.base_text: It was slow, hot work. Once we got inside the slanted hall, the steam was oppressive, everywhere: we were instantly drenched with it, like rot-smelling sweat. Even with the crampons our feet slipped. We held tight to the ropes with steam-wet gloves. The walls and floor twisted and bent as we descended, as if the constant moisture had warped them, but the downward angle stayed vicious.

45452.base_text: All at once we were sliding. Our ropes had gone slack in our hands, no longer connected to anything. There was no time to dig in the crampons; we were already moving too fast, careening down like a grotesque slalom. Neither of us screamed, focused I guess on trying to grab hold of something, anything, but there were no doorways, no light fixtures, nothing but the thick hot slime and the scalding water. I tried to dig my feet into the oozing carpet but my loose rope had entangled me, my pack was in my way, my face was smeared with scalding gunk and I couldn’t open my eyes.

It took a series of shorter climbs to each sideways room, treating them like miniature base camps, places to rest before flinging the grapple up another dozen feet to the next door, the next cube of safety; testing each set of the grapple more thoroughly, belaying each other as best we could in the patently unsafe circumstances. But at length, we’d made it back out.

I’m turning the pieces I have over and over, trying to fit them together, figure it out. But I can’t. I’m missing something, and it’s probably not even something I can find. 45453.base_text: I’d thought he was telling me to commit suicide.

variants.text: I’d thought he was telling me to commit suicide.

45453.base_text: Something was in my room when I got back.

variants.text: Something was in my room when I got back.

45453.base_text: Niko was out—I didn’t know where—and I’d trudged up the creaking stairs to my room still clutching bloody tissues. My bedroom was mostly a waystation now, a point to pass through on our way to the Big Room underneath with its piles of junk and remnants of police tape and my sleeping bag under the foosball table. I could sleep upstairs but my head always throbbed up there, and anyway Downstairs was cool and dark and quiet and all I wanted just then was to zip myself into a nylon cocoon and wait for Niko to get back.

45453.base_text: I froze. Maybe it was Niko, heading down or coming up. I tried to think of something funny to say, a way to surprise him.

45453.base_text: They were like moth wings, but heavier, fleshier. Flailing, flapping sounds, like a hundred children thrashing their arms around, smacking against each other, mid-seizure.

45453.base_text: It was heavy, tortured, huge: the breath of a sick elephant, a dying titan. The floorboards groaned again as if something massive had taken a step, shifted its weight. The wood flexed beneath my feet.

45453.base_text: I looked down. Dust danced on the scuffed hardwood in a strange breeze, sucked under and pushed back out through the gap below the closed door, rhythmic. Each mote sparkled in the dim, distant light, except where the shadow of my legs made them invisible.

45453.base_text: It spoke.

45453.base_text: The sound was distorted, clipped, like a hundred recordings of voices thrown together unmixed, maxing out the dynamic range of reality. It was scream and cry and laughter and words and grunting and hum and song and cough all scraping against each other like geologic faults, painful and unsteady. Unwillingly I remembered how the history lady had looked, thought of the sound something like that might make if it knew what was happening to it, if it wasn’t just an optical illusion but, god, an event, a trauma; thought of the copies of ourselves I’d seen in the dim hallway that first night we went Downstairs and wondered what it would be like if there were a hundred of them all squeezed together in the space where only one should be, each trying to escape and become its own person; wondered whether this was all in my head or whether it mattered if it was; wondered if it mattered that all those voices, those screams and cries and giggles and moans, were all, unmistakably, my own.

45453.base_text: I turned and ran. I half-twisted my ankle on the stairs, cracked my wrist against the banister with enough force to leave a bruise I wouldn’t notice till much later, but I didn’t stop. And as I tore open our front door to flee I crashed straight into Niko, coming in.

45453.base_text: I collapsed into his arms, sobbing, and he let me stay there for a while until I’d calmed down. I clung to him, afraid if I loosened my grip he’d disappear. Like dad, tucking me in. Gone between one blink and the next.

45453.base_text: Eventually I led him upstairs, terrified to go back but also to let him go alone, like he’d offered to in some misplaced stab at courage. But there was nothing in my room. He’d thrown open the door brandishing a hockey stick but everything was exactly as I’d left it, nothing out of place, no cracked floorboards or lingering smell of death or signs of anything unusual at all.

45453.base_text: He had a perpetual headache now. He kept describing it with the word “throbbing” and only that word, as if clinging to the sound of it. Like using a different one would acknowledge the pain too had changed, grown worse, was no longer caged by the word he’d picked to trap it. I could see how much it hurt him to think, to make words, to move around. He ground his teeth. He was being worn down.

45453.base_text: We left to explore down the slippery tunnel late that night. It might have made more sense to start after a good night’s rest, but neither of us could sleep, and spending so much time down there meant night and day were becoming academic concepts anyway. Niko caffeined up (I was jittery enough already), and we loaded our packs with canned food and power bars, thick gloves, and crampons from the sporting goods store. “12 points of contact ensures solid grip on ice,” the box had said. We didn’t expect the manufacturer had tested them on moldy carpet, but it was the best we could do.

45453.base_text: In my pack was also a gun. It had been my dad’s. I hadn’t wanted it but I couldn’t throw it away, nor could I make myself go to the safety courses mom had signed me up for, or take it out from its box at the bottom of my closet with other things I didn’t want to look at. But I hadn’t forgotten I had it. I didn’t tell Niko about the gun. I thought it would make me feel safer but it just felt heavy.

45453.base_text: It had been a hot day and the old house clung to that heat through the night with grim brick desperation. Descending into chillier air was a relief. With every step down the headaches diminished, our mood improved. It was almost addictive, being down there.

45453.base_text: We retraced our route through the upper halls to the top of the shaft and reset the grapples. This time Niko hammered them into the doorjamb, face set, until he’d driven the steel spikes three inches into the wood. Even so, neither of us really expected they’d still be there when we got back.

45453.base_text: Getting down was a familiar exercise now, danger mitigated by procedure and repetition. We retraced our route to the tiled room with the sink. The water was still running, hot and steaming, rushing across the floor to the corner with its angled hallway lined with slimy black carpet. We shined our lights down the hot throat and the steam grabbed their brightness, bounced it back to us innocently. We couldn’t see more than a few body lengths down.

45453.base_text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

variants.text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

45453.base_text: It was slow, hot work. Once we got inside the slanted hall, the steam was oppressive, everywhere: we were instantly drenched with it, like rot-smelling sweat. Even with the crampons our feet slipped. The sludge was deep and slick, a stew of algae and mold and fungal slimes, green-black and stinking of putrefying jungle, of horrible things happening under your carpet, inside your walls. We held tight to the ropes with steam-wet gloves. The walls and floor twisted and bent as we descended, as if the constant moisture had warped them, but the downward angle stayed vicious.

45453.base_text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

variants.text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

45453.base_text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

variants.text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

45453.base_text: All at once we were sliding. Our ropes had gone slack in our hands, no longer connected to anything. There was no time to dig in the crampons; we were already moving too fast, careening down like a grotesque slalom. Neither of us screamed, focused I guess on trying to grab hold of something, anything, but there were no doorways, no light fixtures, nothing but the thick hot slime and the scalding water. I tried to dig my feet into the oozing carpet but my loose rope had entangled me, my pack was in my way, my face was smeared with scalding gunk and I couldn’t open my eyes.

I tried to snag them with my foot, but didn’t even come close. They vanished down the tunnel, trailing rope.

45453.base_text: “Hang on,” I gasped, head filled with the roaring of the water, blinking gunk from my eyes. “Don’t panic. We can do this.”

45453.base_text: “So let’s find out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”

45453.base_text: “Because we don’t even know if there is a bottom.” His face was blotched red with fury, with sweat, with the scorching heat of the air. “Halfway? We have no fucking idea how deep this goes. I should have said this a long time ago. You’re obsessed. You get obsessed a lot, man, let it drag you down. Your stupid records.” He took a deep breath. “Well now you’re obsessed with this place, and it’s blinding you. It’s feeding on you, your obsessions. Multiplying them. You can’t see it, or maybe you don’t want to, but I do. I’m looking right at it. Like the answer to the puzzle.”

45453.base_text: And his hand did close on something, and he pulled himself up, triumphant. His leg was slipping out of my hands, and I couldn’t bear for him to crawl away from me, couldn’t handle the thought of going back up to that world, to any world where everything was wrong and nothing I wanted was possible, so I pulled. I pulled, too hard, and both his hands slipped, and he crashed back into me, only I wasn’t holding onto anything but him any more so both of us tumbled down, faster and faster, slipping and twisting and scraping together down the steepening blood-hot slope, down and down and down into darkness.

It might have made more sense to go down after a good night’s rest, but neither of us could sleep, and spending so much time down there meant night and day were becoming academic concepts anyway. Niko caffeined up (I was jittery enough already), and we loaded our packs with canned food and power bars, thick gloves, and crampons from the sporting goods store. “12 points of contact ensures solid grip on ice,” the box had said. We didn’t expect the manufacturer had tested them on moldy carpet, but it was the best we could do.

45457.base_text: He stared down at me. “Of course back. Are you fucking crazy? Where the fuck else?”

variants.text: He stared down at me. “Of course back. Are you fucking crazy? Where the fuck else?”

45457.base_text: “There’s nothing good up there. Nothing right.” I kicked my foot for purchase, managed to rest at least some weight on a hidden protuberance. “Besides, nothing’s changed. The plan’s still the same.”

variants.text: “There’s nothing good up there. Nothing right.” I kicked my foot for purchase, managed to rest at least some weight on a hidden protuberance. “Besides, nothing’s changed. The plan’s still the same.”
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45457.base_text: “Are you not paying attention?” he hissed, furious. “Something is trying to kill us.”

variants.text: “Are you not paying attention?” he hissed, furious. “Something is trying to kill us.”

45457.base_text: “So let’s figure out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”

variants.text: “So let’s figure out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45457.base_text: “Because we don’t even know if there is a bottom.” His face was blotched red with fury, with sweat, with the scorching heat of the air. “Halfway? We have no fucking idea how deep this goes. I should have said this a long time ago. You’re obsessed. You get obsessed a lot, man, let it drag you down. Your stupid records.” He took a deep breath. “Well now you’re obsessed with this place, and it’s blinding you. It’s feeding on you, your obsessions. Multiplying them. You can’t see it, or maybe you don’t want to, but I do. I’m looking right at it. Like the gorilla in the crowd.”

45457.base_text: I was angry. “If I’m obsessed with anything, it’s with finding a way back. We’re running out of time. We either figure this out, or we’re stuck here forever, in the wrong world. We need each other to get through this.”

45457.base_text: “You’re obsessed with me, too,” he muttered. “When was the last time you hung out with someone else?”

variants.text: “You’re obsessed with me, too,” he muttered. “When was the last time you hung out with someone else?”

45457.base_text: “When was the last time you did?”

variants.text: “When was the last time you did?”

45457.base_text: He shook his head angrily, dismissing this.

variants.text: He shook his head angrily, dismissing this.

45457.base_text: “Our housemates,” I pushed, “when was the last time you hung out with any of them? Anyone other than me?” He stared back, seething. “Their names. I bet you can’t even remember their names.” I was bluffing. But could I remember them, either? Names, faces. No. There was nothing. None of those people mattered, not to me, not to us. We were the only thing that mattered. Getting back to where we’d been, what we’d had. What I’d wanted.

45457.base_text: He shook his head again, violent, like there was something inside it he wanted to dislodge. “You’re living in a fantasy,” he spat, “you always have been. I can’t be what you want me to be, okay? I can’t be what anyone fucking wants me to be. You all have these versions of me in your head, these ideal perfect Nikos, but they’re not real. I can’t live up to them.” He opened his eyes, stared yearningly back up the shaft. “Help me. If you really care about me, help me back up. Don’t be like everyone else. Don’t just fucking use me to get what you want.”

45457.base_text: “Going back’s not going to help. There’s no answers up there.” He wasn’t understanding. I reached for something else. “Those headaches aren’t going away. You think you can live with that pain? Forever?”

45457.base_text: “Better than being fucking dead!” He seemed to realize I wasn’t changing my mind, turned away to reach for a handhold, but there was nothing there, nothing to grip, and he scrabbled pathetically at the slime.

variants.text: “Better than being fucking dead!” He seemed to realize I wasn’t changing my mind, turned away to reach for a handhold, but there was nothing there, nothing to grip, and he scrabbled pathetically at the slime.

45457.base_text: “Is it?” I shouted, angry, desperate. I had to say something, something that would make him stay, keep him here, and my mouth raced ahead of me. “You won’t make it, up there, not with pain like that. We both know you won’t.”

45457.base_text: He tensed, glared down at me. “What the fuck is that supposed to mean?”

variants.text: He tensed, glared down at me. “What the fuck is that supposed to mean?”

45457.base_text: “You know exactly what it means,” I said, shaking. “Never really helped you. I’ve done nothing but help you. I’ve always been there for you. Every fucking time you fall I pick you back up. You’d be dead if it weren’t for me.”

45457.base_text: He shot me with a gaze of such cold fury I cringed. “You’re fucking poison,” he hissed, “you know that? A fucking snake. I wish you’d let me die that night. I wish we’d never met. Let go of me!”

45457.base_text: And his hand did close on something, and he pulled himself up, triumphant. His leg was slipping out of my hands, and I couldn’t bear for him to crawl away from me, couldn’t stand it, couldn’t handle the thought of going back up to that world, to any world where everything was wrong and nothing I wanted was possible, so I pulled. I pulled, too hard, and both his hands slipped, and he crashed back into me, only I wasn’t holding onto anything but him any more so both of us tumbled down, faster and faster, slipping and twisting and scraping together down the steepening blood-hot slope, down and down and down into darkness.

45462.base_text: He took another drag. “Blow me.”

variants.text: He took another drag. “Blow me.”

45462.base_text: I laughed and he flashed me a wicked grin. It felt good to laugh. Even if it was a little bit forced, to make sure he knew that I knew he was kidding.

45462.base_text: “Did I ever tell you,” he finally said, “about that time I went camping by myself, up in Brushwillow?” I shook my head. “Used to do that a lot, after the, uh. Accident.”

45462.base_text: “I went by myself, cause I didn’t want a lot of people around just then, and it’s easier than twisting people’s arms to get them to come with you. Planning around schedules, all that bullshit.” He shifted into citation voice. “‘The one who goes alone can start today; but the one who travels with another must wait until they are ready.’”

45462.base_text: “So this one night I’m up there, alone. I’m in my tent, and it’s dark. Cloudy, no moon. I’m sleeping fine, on my back, you know, head up against the edge of the tent. And then I wake up, cause I hear something, just outside.”

And it was right on the other side of the tent flap. Inches from my face. Like something had pressed its muzzle against the nylon, that thin nothing sheet of ultralight fabric, and was waiting.

45462.base_text: “There was this weird CD-ROM game I was playing,” I said after a while. “It doesn’t exist over here, I guess. You spent all your time wandering around listening to these crazy scientists rant and banging your head against bizarre alien puzzles. I couldn’t make any goddamn sense of it.” I pulled my knees up to my chin. “But I keep thinking about it. Maybe even more, now that I can’t actually play. I’m turning the pieces I have over and over, trying to fit them together, figure it out. But I can’t. I’m missing something, and it’s probably not even something I can find. It’s locked on a CD in another universe. So it’s pointless, but I can’t stop obsessing over it. Just endless frustration, with no way to ever make progress.”

45462.base_text: I tried to take a midterm and it was a disaster. I hadn’t been to class in weeks, which didn’t help, but everything I’d learned earlier had vanished from my brain, neurons reclaimed, I supposed, for more important things. Then I started hallucinating, questions and pencil marks multiplying and layering on themselves even when I looked up from the test, abstractions filling the darkened auditorium, and I had to flee, whispering a hurried apology to the T.A. that I was having a medical emergency. She told me to go home and take care of myself. I was halfway home before I remembered that phrase has a positive meaning, too.

45462.base_text: Something was in my room when I got back. I stood outside the closed door, number two pencil still clutched in my hand, listening. It sounded like an elephant. Heavy, clopping footfalls made the floorboards groan. Wet, agitated breathing rasped. Dust motes danced at my feet in a strange breeze, sucked under and pushed back out through the space below the closed door, rhythmic. Air moved with faint fleshy sounds, like a hundred quiet people flapping their arms, flailing.

I could see how much it hurt him to think, to make words, to move around. He ground his teeth. He was being worn down.

45462.base_text: We left to explore down the slippery tunnel late that night. It might have made more sense to start after a good night’s rest, but neither of us could sleep, and spending so much time down there meant night and day were becoming academic concepts anyway. Niko caffeined up (I was jittery enough already), and we loaded our packs with canned food and power bars, thick gloves, and crampons from the sporting goods store. “12 points of contact ensures solid grip on ice,” the box had said. We didn’t expect the manufacturer had tested them on moldy carpet, but it was the best we could do.

45462.base_text: In my pack was also a gun. I bought it from a place I’d driven past every day on my way to work but never gone into until that morning. The friendly clerk agreed to waive the mandatory waiting period in exchange for the last of my ATM cash. I didn’t tell Niko about the gun. I thought it would make me feel safer but it just felt heavy.

45462.base_text: It had been a hot day and the old house clung to that heat through the night with grim brick desperation. Descending into chillier air was a relief. With every step down the headaches diminished, our mood improved. It was almost addictive, being down there.

45462.base_text: We retraced our route through the upper halls to the top of the shaft and reset the grapples. This time Niko hammered them into the doorjamb, face set, until he’d driven the steel spikes three inches into the wood. Even so, neither of us really expected they’d still be there when we got back.

45462.base_text: Getting down was a familiar exercise now, danger mitigated by procedure and repetition. We retraced our route to the tiled room with the sink via the shortcut we’d found. The water was still running, hot and steaming, rushing across the floor to the corner with its angled hallway lined with slimy black carpet. We shined our lights down the hot throat and the steam grabbed their brightness, bounced it back to us maliciously. We couldn’t see more than a few body lengths down.

variants.text: Getting down was a familiar exercise now, danger mitigated by procedure and repetition. We retraced our route to the tiled room with the sink via the shortcut we’d found. The water was still running, hot and steaming, rushing across the floor to the corner with its angled hallway lined with slimy black carpet. We shined our lights down the hot throat and the steam grabbed their brightness, bounced it back to us maliciously. We couldn’t see more than a few body lengths down.
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: Niko ran a hand through his curls, deflating again in the hot moist air; scratched the hair behind his ear furiously, like a dog with an itch. He was shaking. “Are we sure about this? Really really? Because it sort of seems like a colossally stupid thing to do.”

[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: “You have a better idea?”

variants.text: “You have a better idea?”

45462.base_text: He sighed, looking down the steaming shaft unhappily.

variants.text: He sighed, looking down the steaming shaft unhappily.

45462.base_text: “No, I don’t have a better idea,” he said at last.

variants.text: “No, I don’t have a better idea,” he said at last.

45462.base_text: We pulled on the crampons and the heavy gloves. Harness, rope, knots. Check. Niko pounded two new Grip Monkeys into either side of the angled tunnel entrance. We tied on. Double-check.

[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

variants.text: Then, each holding our rope, kicking hard to sink the sharp toes of the crampons deep into the slimy carpet, we started down.

45462.base_text: It was slow, hot work. Once we got inside the slanted hall, the steam was oppressive, everywhere: we were instantly drenched with it, like rot-smelling sweat. Even with the crampons our feet slipped. The sludge was deep and slick, a stew of algae and mold and fungal slimes, green-black and stinking of putrefying jungle, of horrible things happening under your carpet, inside your walls. We held tight to the ropes with steam-wet gloves. The walls and floor twisted and bent as we descended, as if the constant moisture had warped them, but the downward angle stayed vicious.

[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

variants.text: It was a gullet. We were letting ourselves be swallowed. No—worse. We were forcing ourselves in. Eager. Like we couldn’t wait to be digested.

45462.base_text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

variants.text: We were nearing the end of our sixty meter ropes when everything went to shit.

45462.base_text: All at once we were sliding. Our ropes had gone slack in our hands, no longer connected to anything. There was no time to dig in the crampons; we were already moving too fast, careening down like a grotesque slalom. Neither of us screamed, focused I guess on trying to grab hold of something, anything, but there were no doorways, no light fixtures, nothing but the thick hot slime and the scalding water. I tried to dig my feet into the oozing carpet but my loose rope had entangled me, my pack was in my way, my face was smeared with scalding gunk and I couldn’t open my eyes.

45462.base_text: My hand closed on Niko’s leg and I grabbed it. A moment later the floor angle shifted and he cried out, threw his body sideways, brought us both to a shuddering, squelchy stop.

variants.text: My hand closed on Niko’s leg and I grabbed it. A moment later the floor angle shifted and he cried out, threw his body sideways, brought us both to a shuddering, squelchy stop.

45462.base_text: We were soaked through, overheating. Scalding water ran past us down the slope. I blinked my eyes open and saw he’d wedged himself into a kink in the tunnel. One of his knees was scraped open and a dull red mark on his forehead was beginning to swell. But he’d done it. He’d stopped us.

45462.base_text: Ropes slithered down the tunnel past us, followed moments later by two grapples still tied to their ends. Niko reached out to grab one with his free hand, but his weight shifted, and he had to throw the hand back against a wall to re-brace, cursing. I tried to snag them with my foot, but didn’t even come close. They vanished down the tunnel, trailing rope.

45462.base_text: Niko’s face was tight. He tilted his head down toward me. “This was a mistake. God, we’re so fucking stupid. Ryan, man. We have to go back.”

variants.text: Niko’s face was tight. He tilted his head down toward me. “This was a mistake. God, we’re so fucking stupid. Ryan, man. We have to go back.”

45462.base_text: “Hang on,” I gasped, head filled with the roaring of the water, blinking gunk from my eyes. “Don’t panic. We can do this.”

variants.text: “Hang on,” I gasped, head filled with the roaring of the water, blinking gunk from my eyes. “Don’t panic. We can do this.”
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: “Man, I’m barely holding on. I don’t know how much longer I can keep from slipping. We have to try to climb back up.”

variants.text: “Man, I’m barely holding on. I don’t know how much longer I can keep from slipping. We have to try to climb back up.”

45462.base_text: “Back?” I said, confused. “You want to go back?”

variants.text: “Back?” I said, confused. “You want to go back?”

45462.base_text: He stared down at me. “Of course back. Are you fucking crazy? Where the fuck else?”

variants.text: He stared down at me. “Of course back. Are you fucking crazy? Where the fuck else?”

45462.base_text: “There’s nothing good up there. Nothing right.” I kicked my foot for purchase, managed to rest at least some weight on a hidden protuberance. “Besides, nothing’s changed. The plan’s still the same.”

variants.text: “There’s nothing good up there. Nothing right.” I kicked my foot for purchase, managed to rest at least some weight on a hidden protuberance. “Besides, nothing’s changed. The plan’s still the same.”
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: “Are you not paying attention?” he hissed, furious. “Something is trying to kill us.”

variants.text: “Are you not paying attention?” he hissed, furious. “Something is trying to kill us.”

45462.base_text: “So let’s find out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”

variants.text: “So let’s find out how to stop it.” I tried to keep my tone reasonable. “We’re halfway down already. Climbing back up will be hard, regardless. Why not get all the way to the bottom first?”
[Paragraph not present in this version]

45462.base_text: “Because we don’t even know if there is a bottom.” His face was blotched red with fury, with sweat, with the scorching heat of the air. “Halfway? We have no fucking idea how deep this goes. I should have said this a long time ago. You’re obsessed. You get obsessed a lot, man, let it drag you down. Your stupid records.” He took a deep breath. “Well now you’re obsessed with this place, and it’s blinding you. It’s feeding on you, your obsessions. Multiplying them. You can’t see it, or maybe you don’t want to, but I do. I’m looking right at it. Like the answer to the puzzle.”

45462.base_text: I was angry. “If I’m obsessed with anything, it’s with finding a way back. We’re running out of time. We either figure this out, or we’re stuck here forever, on the wrong side. We need each other to get through this.”

45462.base_text: “You’re obsessed with me, too,” he muttered. “When was the last time you hung out with someone else?”

variants.text: “You’re obsessed with me, too,” he muttered. “When was the last time you hung out with someone else?”

45462.base_text: “When was the last time you did?”

variants.text: “When was the last time you did?”

45462.base_text: He shook his head angrily, dismissing this.

variants.text: He shook his head angrily, dismissing this.

45462.base_text: “Our housemates,” I pushed, “when was the last time you hung out with any of them? Anyone other than me?” He stared back, seething. “Their names. I bet you can’t even remember their names.” I was bluffing. But could I remember them, either? Names, faces. No. There was nothing. None of those people mattered, not to me, not to us. We were the only thing that mattered. Getting back to where we’d been, what we’d had. What I’d wanted.

45462.base_text: He shook his head again, violent, like there was something inside it he wanted to dislodge. “You’re living in a fantasy,” he spat, “you always have been. I can’t be what you want me to be, okay? I can’t be what anyone fucking wants me to be. You all have these versions of me in your head, these ideal perfect Nikos, but they’re not real. I can’t live up to them.” He opened his eyes, stared yearningly back up the shaft. “Help me. If you really care about me, help me back up. Don’t be like everyone else. Don’t just fucking use me to get what you want.”

45462.base_text: “Going back’s not going to help. There’s no answers up there.” He wasn’t understanding. I reached for something else. “Those headaches aren’t going away. You think you can live with that pain? Forever?”

45462.base_text: “Better than being fucking dead!” He seemed to realize I wasn’t changing my mind, turned away to reach for a handhold, but there was nothing there, nothing to grip, and he scrabbled pathetically at the slime.

variants.text: “Better than being fucking dead!” He seemed to realize I wasn’t changing my mind, turned away to reach for a handhold, but there was nothing there, nothing to grip, and he scrabbled pathetically at the slime.

45462.base_text: “Is it?” I shouted, angry, desperate. I had to say something, something that would make him stay, keep him here, and my mouth raced ahead of me. “You won’t make it, up there, not with pain like that. We both know you won’t.”

45462.base_text: He tensed, glared down at me. “What the fuck is that supposed to mean?”

variants.text: He tensed, glared down at me. “What the fuck is that supposed to mean?”

45462.base_text: “You know exactly what it means,” I said, shaking. “Never really helped you. I’ve done nothing but help you. I’ve always been there for you. Every fucking time you fall I pick you back up. You’d be dead if it weren’t for me.”

45462.base_text: He shot me with a gaze of such cold fury I cringed. “You’re fucking poison,” he hissed, “you know that? A fucking snake. I wish you’d let me die that night. I wish we’d never met. Let go of me!”

45462.base_text: And his hand did close on something, and he pulled himself up, triumphant. His leg was slipping out of my hands, and I couldn’t bear for him to crawl away from me, couldn’t handle the thought of going back up to that world, to any world where everything was wrong and nothing I wanted was possible, so I pulled. I pulled, too hard, and both his hands slipped, and he crashed back into me, only I wasn’t holding onto anything but him any more so both of us tumbled down, faster and faster, slipping and twisting and scraping together down the steepening blood-hot slope, down and down and down into darkness.
